I downloaded swt 3.1 m2 and compiled on my mac G5 running gentoo ppc64. I got
the following errors when I executed a small test program.

(<unknown>:7070): GLib-GObject-WARNING **: type name `' is too short

(<unknown>:7070): GLib-GObject-CRITICAL **: file gobject.c: line 819
(g_object_new): assertion `G_TYPE_IS_OBJECT (object_type)' failed
Exception in thread "main" org.eclipse.swt.SWTError: No more handles
	at org.eclipse.swt.SWT.error(SWT.java:2717)

 My system: kernel 2.6.9, gtk+ 2.4.13, glib 2.4.7, and gnome 2.8.0.

My system is Gentoo Linux ppc64 2004.3.
Sorry for the inconvenience.
*** Bug 79129 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Are you trying to run in 32 bit mode or 64 bit mode?
Did you downloaded SWT for Linux GTK AMD64? This version contains the 64 bit 
version of the SWT jar.

I ran it in 64-bit mode. I tried also the gtk amd64 version 3.1m3, but failed
too with different error messages(see following).

Created an attachment (id=16056)
java dump message

Yang:

The crash in comment 5 maybe due to the way you rebuilt the 64 bit sources. 
Since I don't have a Mac G5 running gentoo ppc64, it's going to be a little 
bit of a try and error kind of approach...

1. Which JVM are you using?
2. How do you build the C library? Make sure you set
SWT_PTR_CFLAGS=-DSWT_PTR_SIZE_64
as set by our build.sh script for the x86_64 model before running the makefile.

I use ibm jdk for ppc64 1.4.2
I built the so files by modifying the build.sh.

I tried to build the so files by defining SWT_PTR_FLAGS as you instructed, but
the same errors as before. I built the jar files from java source too, no avail.

please paste the modified build.sh you used.

please do the following:
open a console
go to the folder containing your swt shared libraries
ldd libswt-pi-gtk-xxxx.so

paste the output of the previous command (replace xxxx with your version)

Any ideas?

Kim: do you know if someone now contributes Eclipse builds for GTK Mac G5 PPC 
and/or GTK IBM PPC (PPC64) platforms? Thanks!

No, nobody contributes the builds for the platforms specified. The source build
scripts do not support these platforms either. If they are required, let me know
and we can patch them.

Oh, please do it. I would be VERY GRATEFUL if you could patch it, so that I
could use eclipse to do java programs. I planned to use eclipse to develop EJB
based applications for some projects with my PowerMac G5 running Gentoo PPC64
Linux. I've had the needed software in place, including JDK(ibm 1.4.2 for
PPC64),JBoss 4.0, and MySQL 4.0.22, the only part missing now is Java IDE. I
used eclipse 2 before and  loved it for Java application development very much.
Unfortunately I cant use my  beloved Java IDE in my new machine anymore; it's a
very much frustration to me, after I did many trials in vain.

To clarify, are you looking for the ability to run Eclipse on a Linux-GTK-ppc64
platform (But ppc64 machine is a mac g5)
Yes, exactly.

The source builds have been modified to support Linux-gtk-ppc64 with src build
>= N20041203.  

https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=57897

However, I think the issue is that the uname -m on your machine is not ppc64 or
ppc but rather "Power Macintosh".  Please confirm the contents of uname -m on
your machine.  If this is the case, we'll update the source builds scripts to
support this configuration and will ask you to test it given that we do not have
access to this os-ws-arch combination.

Thank you very much!
For my PowerMac G5 running Gentoo PPC64 Linux, "uname -m" returns "ppc64", not
"Power Macintosh". Now I am going to download the latest build of eclipse, and
test it.
Thank you again.

I downloaded the build N20041207 and tried to compile it using build script, but
failed with following messages when I used -debug flag for ant(see next attachment).
The building process actually hanged in "init" stage(I used ctrl+c to terminate
it), dont know why. Eclipse 3.0 can be built successfully in the same environment.

Created an attachment (id=16446)
Building messages until hang

I also tried to execute a small java program using swt-N20041207, but failed with:

Exception in thread "main" java.lang.NoSuchMethodError: fixedClassInitProc
        at org.eclipse.swt.internal.Callback.bind(Native Method)
        at org.eclipse.swt.internal.Callback.<init>(Callback.java:123)
        at org.eclipse.swt.internal.Callback.<init>(Callback.java:78)
        at org.eclipse.swt.internal.Callback.<init>(Callback.java:60)
        at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.createDisplay(Display.java:731)
        at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.create(Display.java:706)
        at org.eclipse.swt.graphics.Device.<init>(Device.java:123)
        at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.<init>(Display.java:412)
        at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.<init>(Display.java:408)
        at Hello.main(Hello.java:10)

In certain environments, the build will hang on the javadoc generation.

Append your compilelog.txt to the bug and I'll take a look.

Also, on older linux distros, we have had to set an environment variable to run
a successful build.  I'm not sure if this is the case with your setup.

export LD_ASSUME_KERNEL=2.2.5

Now it goes a little bit further, But I still could not make build it.
Compilelog.txt attached.
LD_ASSUME_KERNEL doesnt work on my system.

Created an attachment (id=16477)
compilelog.txt

I just tried the SWT N20041208 for gtk64(it didnt work for gtk version,the error
messages as my previous post), it worked. Great!

Hi Yang,

What did you do to make it work? Did you had to use the following line or not?
export LD_ASSUME_KERNEL=2.2.5

Thanks!

No, I did not use it. I compiled glibc using "nptlonly", LD_ASSUME_KERNEL   is
not supported. I just compiled those source files, and tried to execute a small
program using them and 2 swt jar files. I also copied them together with swt jar
files to eclipse 3.01, 3.01 worked though it seemed a little bit unstable in my
environment.
closing PR.
